notes: Double stacks frequently combine QB + two WRs, or WR + TE.
RBs are less commonly included in stacks; usually only high-receiving backs.
Larger stacks (three teammates) used primarily in projected shootouts.
Bringbacks tilt heavily WR (73%), mirroring slate-breaking WR ceilings.
RB bringback is highly slate- or matchup-dependent.
Double bringback is rare, but present in high-total game onslaughts.
Wide receiver is the most common FLEX, notably above 55%.
RB in FLEX increases in injury/uncertainty slates; TE rarely optimal unless exceptional value.
Flex slot nearly always used on high-ceiling position based on matchup volatility.
Winning lineups blend 2–3 chalk ('core') plays with 3+ leverage/contrarian options.
A true single-digit-ownership player ('differentiator') is present in ~89% of winners.
Leaving > $1,000 of salary unused nearly eliminates winning odds.
Most winners stay within $500 of cap, but uniqueness gained by skipping full $50k when possible.

positional_combination.default_structure: 2 RB, 3 WR, 1 TE, 1 FLEX, 1 QB, 1 DST
notes: Punters at DST are almost always featured in winning builds.
TE is more often faded unless punt-priced or stacked.
Every winner had at least one player <7% owned.
Leverage mostly found at WR/FLEX and DST; rarely at RB.
Slate-breaking contrarians outperform projections substantially.
Game onslaughts more viable when mid-priced players and projected shootouts align.
Double bringbacks or four total players from same game represented a growing trend (esp. 2023–2024).
Rarely paying up at defense; most use sub-$3,200 options.
Correlates with negative game scripts for chalk offenses.
Sharp lineup construction maximizes points while finding value/undervalued breakouts in pricing.
Winning lineups often benefit from late swaps into lower-owned 'late hammer' games.
Salary uniqueness (via sub-$50k usage) differentiates as projections get sharper.
